citation.article-title: Mycobacterium marseillense sp. nov., Mycobacterium timonense sp. nov. and Mycobacterium bouchedurhonense sp. nov., members of the Mycobacterium avium complex
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium marseillense sp. nov.
Mycobacterium marseillense (mar.seil.len′se. N.L. neut. adj. marseillense pertaining to Marseille, where the first strains were isolated).
Cells are small (0.92–1.03×0.50–0.54 μm), acid-fast, Gram-positive bacilli.
Colonies are non-pigmented and grow on 5 % sheep blood agar, Middlebrook 7H10 agar and egg-based Löwenstein–Jensen slants after 10 days incubation at 30 °C.
Exhibits a unique morphology with pseudo-mycelium formation.
Hydrolyses Tween 80, but does not reduce potassium tellurite.

It shares 96.4–99.8 % 16S rRNA gene and 93.3–97.8 % rpoB, 94.0–97.5 % hsp65 and 35.5–87.2 % ITS-1 sequence similarities with MAC reference strains M. avium ATCC 25291T, M. intracellulare ATCC 15985, M. chimaera DSM 44623T and M. colombiense CIP 108962T.
The type strain is 5356591T (=CIP 109828T =CCUG 56325T =CSUR P30T), sequevar MAC-X1, which was recovered from sputum.
Strain 62863 (=CCUG 56324 =CIP 109832 =CSUR P31), sequevar MAC-D, is a reference strain.
